THE PROPOSAL

II.

INTRODUCTION

2.
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has significantly contributed to the power sector in
the Maldives through its loans and technical assistance (TA) programs to help meet electricity
demands  in  the  capital  island  of  Malé  and  to  strengthen  institutional  capacity  of  the  sector.
Consistent  with  its  strategy  of  supporting  balanced  regional  development,  ADB  has  shifted  its
focus to rural electrification in the outer islands, where the majority of the country’s poor reside
and  poor  electricity  supply  has  constrained  economic  and  social  development.  The  proposed
Project supports the new focus and has been included in ADB’s lending program for 2001 and
was prepared under ADB project preparatory TA1 completed in January 2001.  The Project is an
integral  part  of  the  least-cost  development  plan  for  the  power  sector,  and  is  accorded  high
priority  by  the  Government.    The  Appraisal  Mission  was  conducted  from  14  to  26  September
2001.2  This  report  is  based  on  the  findings  of  the  TA  report  and  the  Appraisal  Mission,  and
information provided by the Government. The project framework is in Appendix 1.

III.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1.

Location

The  Maldives  comprises  about  1,200  varied  and  diverse  islands,  grouped  into  20
3.
administrative  atolls.3  The  islands  form  a  chain  of  820  kilometers  (km)  long  and  130  km  at  its
widest point, set in the Indian Ocean to the southwest of India. Only 33 inhabited islands have a
land area of more than 1 km2, and only 3 each have an area larger than 3 km2. The Maldives
has no rivers, lakes, or streams. While there are occasional gales (on average 12 days a year)
and  tropical  thunderstorms  (on  average  23  days  a  year),  the  Maldives  lies  outside  the  main
areas of tropical cyclones.

The Maldives population of 269,010 is scattered in about 200 inhabited islands4 and 83
4.
resort  islands.  About  20  islands  have  more  than  2,000  people;  50  islands  1,000-2,000;  80
islands, 500-1,000; and 50 islands, less than 500 people. The widely dispersed population and
the economic  constraints  imposed  by  lack  of  land-based resources and the diseconomies of

2.

Economic Growth

5.
Economic growth has been strong, with an annual average rate of 10 percent during the
1970s and 1980s, and 6-7 percent in the 1990s. The economy is expected to grow at the rate of
5-6  percent  over  the  next  five  years.  Per  capita  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  2000  was
provisionally estimated at $2,059.5  The population growth rate is relatively high, averaging 3.4
percent  during  1985-1990  and  falling  to  1.9  percent  during  1995-2000.  Assuming  the  current
mortality rate, a reduction in fertility rates, and no migration, the population is expected to reach
300,000  by  2005  and  500,000  by  2023.  The  rapid  population  growth  rate  coupled  with  high
economic  growth  continues  to  place  a  significant  demand  for  infrastructure  and  financial
resources in the country.

6.
A quarter of the national population or about 70,000 people live in the capital island of
Malé, which has a land area of only 2.1 km2. It is crowded and has one of the highest population
densities in the region. The 1995 census indicated that most of Malé’s population is housed in
dwellings  accommodating  over  10  people,  with  a  quarter  of  the  households  accommodating
over  14  people.  Despite  the  Government’s  efforts,  the  large  disparities  between  Malé  and  the
outer islands continue to widen. There is significant migration from the outer islands to Malé for
better income and living standards. Providing the outer islands with a reliable and sustainable
electricity supply will help reduce the disparities and ease the substantial population pressures
on Malé.

3. 

The Power Sector

a.

Energy Situation

7.
The  Maldives  has  no  known  indigenous  petroleum,  gas,  or  coal  resources  and
hydropower  is  not  feasible  because  of  the  topography.  Firewood  and  petroleum  are  the  only
commercial fuels and firewood is a common cooking fuel on most of the outer islands. The loss
of  tree  cover  has  become  serious  and  the  Government  has  restricted  on  cutting  and  requires
that  for  each  tree  cut,  two  must  be  planted.  However,  it  is  unable  to  enforce  the  regulation
properly  and  much  firewood  is  cut  illegally.    Petroleum  is  imported  as  refined  product  by  the
State  Trading  Organization  and  a  number  of  private  entrepreneurs.  Diesel  is  largely  used  to
generate electricity in the capital, and for about 1,000 electricity generators in the outer islands.
It  is  expected  that  the  country  will  continue  to  rely  on  imported  petroleum  fuel  for  power
generation.  Petroleum  products  are  also  used  for  transportation,  fishing,  household  cooking,
and  other  minor  uses.  Petroleum  product  imports  account  for  a  significant  percentage  of  total
imports.  Solar energy is used in traditional ways, such as for drying fish and for heating water in
some resorts. It is also harnessed for remote area telecommunications and navigational aids.

b.

General Structure of the Sector

Various  organizations  provide  electricity  in  the  Maldives  including  the  State  Electric

electricity to Malé and to 20 of the larger outer islands, altogether more than half of the nation’s

9.
The  IDCs  are  community-based  extensions  of  the  Government  and  are  the  grassroot
institutions in the development of the islands.  NGOs running power supply systems range from
community-based  formal  and  registered  organizations  to  informal  community  clubs  using  the
sale  of  electricity  as  a  fund-raising  activity.  The  private  sector  companies  are  operated  and
owned  by  small-scale  family  entrepreneurs,  or  by  substantial  private  companies.  Some  outer
islands have more than one electricity provider, often supplying the same geographic area. Of
97 focus islands,6 about 50 have electricity systems owned and operated by IDCs, 20 by private
companies, 10 by NGOs, and 20 by STELCO. Regulating generation, distribution, and utilization
including tariff setting is the responsibility of MEB. At present, electricity generation is entirely by
diesel-based  generators.  Distribution  is  almost  exclusively  by  underground  cables,  using  low-
voltage,  three-phase,  four-wire  400/230  volt  cables  augmented  by  11  kV  high-voltage  cables
where  needed.  Except  on  the  largest  islands,  distribution  from  the  power  station  is  by  low-
voltage cables.

10.
Both  electricity  tariffs  and  tariff  structures  vary  between  islands  since  tariff-setting
mechanisms are under de facto decentralized decision making with consideration for the local
context.7  In Malé, the electricity tariffs are Rf2.0-Rf4.0 ($0.16-$0.31) per kilowatt-hour (kWh). In
outer islands with electricity supplied by STELCO, tariffs are Rf2.5-Rf4.0 ($0.20-$0.31) per kWh.
For  the  outer  islands  with  private  companies  or  local  communities  supplying  electricity,  the
average tariffs are usually in the range of Rf3.50-Rf6.00 ($0.27-$0.47) per kWh, and can be as
high  as  Rf10.00  ($0.78)  per  kWh  in  some  islands.  Unlike  in  many  other  developing  countries,
collecting the electricity bill  has  not  been an issue in the Maldives. Most households pay their
dues on time partly due to peer pressure in the small and closed nature of island society.

c.

The Project Area

Although an official poverty line for the Maldives has not yet been established, the Vulnerability
and  Poverty  Assessment  (VPA)  report  conducted  in  1998  by  the  Government,  with  the

12.
The  percentage  of  the  population  with  access  to  electricity  has  rapidly  grown  over  the
last decade. In 1990, it was estimated that one third of the nation's population had no access to
electricity. The percentage had fallen to 13 percent by 1995, and to 7 percent in 1998. Although
access to electricity has improved considerably, electricity supply systems in the outer islands
are  generally  inadequate.  Operation  hours  are  often  restricted,  quality  is  usually  poor,  and
systems are inefficient. Poor quality of electricity supply suppresses demand, as customers are
often  reluctant  to  invest  in  electrical  appliances,  which  have  only  a  short  operating  life.
Currently,  many of the outer island population have access to electricity for only 5-12 hours a
day.  The  efficiency  of  power  supply  systems  in  most  of  the  outer  islands  is  low.  Undersized
cables,  inaccurate  customer  meters,  mismatch  of  the  system  to  the  load,  and  inefficient
generating  plants  have  all  led  to  high  system  losses.  The  unreliable  electricity  supply  in  the
outer islands limits the living standards of the population, inhibits a wide range of development
on  the  islands,  and  increases  the  vulnerability  of  the  population.  The  VPA  report  identified
adequate electricity supply as one of the key variables in the human vulnerability index (HVI) for
the  Maldives.  Access  to  reliable  and  adequate  electricity  supply  contributes  to  well-being,  and
social  and  human  resource  development,  and  provides  greater  opportunities  for  income-
generating activities.

13.
Each year, the Ministry of Atolls Administration (MAA) has provided about 20 electrical
generators with capacity ranging from 15 kW to 80 kW to the outer islands on an adhoc grant
basis.  Over  a  three-year  period,  about  50  islands  have  received  generators  as  a  free  gift.  In
addition, MAA has administered development loans with a revolving fund scheme in the amount
of  Rf20  million  for  island  electrification  from  the  Government  Treasury  Fund  and  the  Bank  of
Maldives. Until April 2001, 17 islands had received assistance amounting to Rf6.3 million from
the Treasury loan scheme, and 39 islands had received loans amounting to Rf8.6 million from
the Bank of Maldives.  The repayment period is usually five years including a six-month grace
period. The interest rate of the Treasury loan is 8 percent per annum. In the case of the Bank of
Maldives, the interest rate is 12 percent, but MAA subsidizes 4 percent annually from its budget,
making  the  actual  interest  rate  equivalent  to  8  percent  per  annum.  These  financing  schemes
have  helped  the  islands,  but  are  not  sufficient  to  meet  the  demand  for  upgrading  the  power
supply systems in the outer islands.

The safety standards in distribution networks and house wiring are poor, largely due to
14.
lack of skilled manpower to properly inspect and test the equipment and electrical installations.
Small private suppliers especially tend to ignore the quality of supply requirements, and literally
generate electricity out of a backroom in their home. This is a major concern of the customers,
who invariably rate improved reliability and quality of supply as very important. The Government
has realized the problem and initiated internal discussions about placing MEB staff or appointing
MEB  representatives  in  each  of  the  atolls  to  carry  out  the  regulatory  and  inspection  function
properly.

4.

Key Sector Issues

a.

Regional Development

15.
Regional  disparity  between  Malé  and  the  outer  islands  has  continued  to  be  a  key
development  issue.    According  to  the  VPA  report,  income  disparities  between  Malé  and  the
outer islands were in the order of 2:1, with the ratio increasing to 3:1 when the lowest average
per  capita  income  is  considered.  In  addition,  inequalities  in  access  to  social  and  physical
infrastructure  and  services  between  Malé  and  the  outer  islands  were  found  to  be  far  more
pronounced,  averaging  4:1  on  a  composite  index  that  took  account  of  various  indicators.  The
rapid growth of the population in the Maldives has increased the urgency of providing a broad
range  of  social  and  physical  infrastructure  in  the  outer  islands.  The  wide  dispersal  of  the

 5

population  inevitably  raises  the  costs  in  providing  these  services.  It  is  recognized  that  an
excessive development focus on Malé will constrain the future growth of the country. Therefore,
regional development is considered as a key factor in easing the development pressure on Malé
and at the same time addressing equity concerns.

b.

Institutional Capacity of Island Power Utilities

16.
Except  for  those  islands  where  electricity  is  supplied  by  STELCO,  the  outer  island
communities  and  the  island  administration  are  generally  incapable  of  proper  operation  and
maintenance (O&M) of power supply systems. They do not have the level of specialized utility
management  skills  required  to  operate  the  power  supply  systems  at  optimal  level,  and  do  not
adequately  take  account  of  the  long-term  capital  replacement  requirements.  Almost  all  power
station  managers  and  operators  lack  the  skills  needed  to  efficiently  operate  a  power  supply
system.  There  is  no  appreciation  of  the  need  to  monitor  the  efficiencies  of  operations,  fuel
consumption,  or  distribution  losses.    Furthermore,  bookkeeping  and  cost-accounting  systems
are very simple, and sometimes totally neglected.  There is a critical need to build the capacity
of outer island power supply utilities to efficiently manage and operate power supply systems.

c.

Lending Practices and Legal Issues

At present, many outer island power supply systems are run by the communities through
17.
IDCs, or NGOs such as clubs and associations.  Although these groups are generally accepted
by  the  communities,  they  are  not  legal  entities  and  there  is  confusion  about  ownership  of  the
assets  and  liabilities.  Furthermore,  currently  no  laws  in  the  Maldives  recognize  IDCs,  island
communities, or island community groups as legal entities. Nevertheless, it is common practice
for the Government or the Bank of Maldives to lend to island community groups such as IDCs
for development purposes. Such loans are provided by the Bank of Maldives with a government
guarantee. In the case of loans from the Government's revolving Treasury Fund, island chiefs
are  required  to  acknowledge  receipt  of  loans  on  behalf  of  the  island  communities.  IDCs  and
informal  island  groups  are  also  able  to  obtain  small  commercial  loans  for  capital  investments.
Except for a few rare cases, the Government or the Bank of Maldives has not had problems with
loan repayment by the island communities.

18.
The  Government,  however,  wishes  to  ensure  that  island  communities  are  legally
accountable for using and repaying the loans as well as for the power supply. The Government
considers it important to legalize these power supply utilities so as to effectively regulate them
as well as to instill a culture of accountability and self-governance in island communities.

19.
The  Government  has  considered  various  options  of  legalizing  the  outer  island  power
supply  utilities  under  current  Maldivian  law,  in  particular  the  Companies  Act  (10/96).  It
concluded  that  the  existing  legal  framework  could  not  be  applied  to  achieve  the  objectives  of
community ownership and involvement, without significant distortion of the intents and purposes
of the Companies Act. The Government therefore decided to prepare new legislation to provide
for legal electricity cooperatives to be established on the outer islands following the community-
based  approach,  or  amend  the  existing  laws  to  permit  recognition  of  IDCs  and  other  island
community groups as legal entities. Where an existing electricity supplier is a private company
legally  established  under  the  Companies  Act  and  the  island  community  prefers,  the  private
company may continue to supply electricity on that island.

d.

Sector Regulation

20.
In January 1998, the Government established MEB to succeed the regulatory part of the
Maldives Electricity Board and gave it responsibility for establishing the standards of electricity
supply,  regulating  the  electricity  service  providers,  and  setting  tariffs.  It  has  an  immense  task,
considering the widely dispersed geography of the country and the need for qualified people to
prepare the regulatory codes and standards, inspect, and test equipment and site, and regulate
electricity  tariffs.  Yet,  MEB  has  only  a  skeleton  staff  and  its  current  operational  practices  are
adhoc  and  informal.  There  is  no  national  regulatory  code  and  standards  for  electricity  supply,
leading to poor safety and quality standards of power supply systems, particularly in the outer
islands. Further, MEB needs to develop more comprehensive pricing principles for setting tariffs.
Strengthening MEB and establishing a national code and standards for electricity supply are the
Government's priorities.

21.
The safety standards in distribution networks and house wiring in the outer islands are
being  compromised  due  to  lack  of  skilled  people  to  inspect  and  test  the  equipment  and  sites.
Each island chief is expected to assist MEB in ensuring that MEB regulations are complied with,
while at the same time he is in charge of the IDC that may be operating the electricity supply
utility.  Given the conflicting obligations and responsibilities, it is often impossible to enforce the
MEB  regulations  properly.  It  is  therefore  important  that  at  least  one  electrical  inspector
representing MEB be stationed in most of the atolls. This would enable MEB to encourage and
enforce compliance with its regulations in the islands. In some locations, an electrical inspector
may be shared between atolls.

e.

Environmental Protection

22.
All the islands in the Maldives are built entirely of coral, and land area never exceeds 13
km2. The maximum elevation is not more than 2-3 meters above sea level, making the country
vulnerable to sea level rise. The Maldives has a special stake in the debate over global warming
from greenhouse gases and consequent sea level rise. It is expected that introducing renewable
energy  technologies  such  as  solar  photovoltaics  (PV)  and  windmills  would  contribute  to
environmental conservation.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A.

Rationale

41. 
Power  supply  systems  in  most  of  the  outer  islands  have  been  developed  on  an  adhoc
basis and unprofessionally by the island communities. The results are an unreliable supply, low
efficiency, poor quality, and high costs. Although most of the island populations are connected
to some form of electricity, the poor and unreliable electricity supply has constrained economic
and  social  development  in  the  outer  islands.  This  has  led  to  considerable  disparities  between
Malé and the outer islands. The provision of reliable, affordable, and efficient electricity supply in
the outer islands is essential to reduce the disparities among the islands, and to reduce poverty
and improve the quality of life of the outer island populations.

42.
The  project  preparatory  TA  report  concluded  that  diesel  generation  is  the  least-cost
option  in  the  outer  islands  and  that  other  renewable  energy  technologies  aside  from  solar  PV
power and windmill power are not promising in the medium term.  The TA report also studied in
substantial detail the feasibility of generating electricity using renewable energy from wind and
PV, which would be integrated with diesel generation. However, generating power using these
forms  of  renewable  energy  would  be  very  costly,  with  average  costs  of  more  than  $1.00  per
kWh  for  delivered  electricity.    For  this  Project,  a  grant  financing  from  the  Global  Environment

 11

Facility (GEF) was sought for the hybrid pilot renewable energy projects comprising PV-diesel
and wind-diesel as well as a set of barrier removal initiatives that are expected to enhance the
adoption  of  renewable  energy  technologies.    This  project  concept  was  accepted  by  GEF  and
entered in the GEF pipeline for grant financing.  There was also some concern that perhaps the
project  costs  and  benefit  estimates  of  the  renewable  energy  technologies  included  in  the  TA
might have been too conservative. Therefore, the findings of the TA were reviewed by another
set  of  independent  staff  consultants  engaged  for  fact-finding  and  appraisal.  It  was  confirmed
that electricity generation in the outer islands through PV and windmill is not economically viable
at  present,  even  when  such  projects  are  replicated  in  large  numbers.    The  cost  of  such
renewable energy would be about 10 times the alternative fuel cost of electricity generation from
diesel  generator  sets.  Sensitivity  tests  indicate  that  this  remains  uneconomic  even  if  fuel  oil
prices  increase  more  than  5  times,  or  if  the  carbon  emission  “tax”  or  indirect  cost  increases
more  than  100  times.  Although  generating  electricity  with  windmill  has  proved  feasible  and
affordable in some countries in the world, it will be very costly due to the small size of the wind
turbine  units  required  and  the  relatively  low  average  wind  speeds  in  the  Maldives.  Solar  PV
electricity supply is generally feasible only for very small loads or for isolated users who have no
access  to  a  local  community-based  power  supply,  but  it  is  still  much  more  costly  than  diesel
power supply in the outer islands. This evaluation and sensitivity analysis are described in more
detail  in  Appendix  3.  Based  on  the  above  analysis,  all  generation  capacity  to  be  added  under
the Project will be diesel-based.

43.
Poor  power  system  management  skills,  coupled  with  lack  of  specialized  utility  financial
management and professional engineering skills for planning, design, construction supervision,
and O&M have been a major obstacle to developing sustainable power supply systems in the
outer islands.  The demand for electricity in the outer islands has rapidly increased due to strong
economic  growth.  This  trend,  which  is  expected  to  continue  in  the  future,  will  place  a  major
burden  on  the  human  resources  of  the  power  sector,  particularly  in  the  outer  islands.  The

other  agencies  involved  under  the  Project  and  the  electricity  sector  regulator  is  equally
important for successful completion of the Project and proper regulation of power supply utilities.

shared  in  a  balanced  manner  among  the  population,  and  that  the  Project  addresses  equity
concerns by improving the standards of living, reducing the vulnerability of the populations in the
outer islands, and ensuring that the electricity supply is affordable to the poor. In addition, the
JFPR component will strengthen the poverty reduction impacts of the Project.

79.
The  Project  involves  no  resettlement  and,  if  land  is  required,  the  Government  will
allocate  lands  that  will  not  involve  resettlement.  Existing  power  station  buildings  will  be  used
wherever possible. New powerhouses, if any, will be small, and for the most part will not require
land exceeding 400 m2. There is no private land ownership in the country and all lands belong
to  the  Government.  The  constitution  and  laws  of  the  country  give  atoll  chiefs  the  authority  to
allocate land up to 400 m2 for public use. Reflecting the importance ADB places on careful and
effective  implementation  of  land  acquisition,  the  following  will  be  conditions  for  subproject
approval: (i) confirmation that no resettlement of people or impact on livelihood is involved, and
(ii) receipt from appropriate authorities of approval of the allocation of government-owned land.
The PMU will have overall responsibility for coordinating the implementation of land allocation.

various  categories  versus  the  number  of  potential  total  consumers  in  those  categories  in  an

81.

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Economic and Financial Analyses

1.

Project Basis

82.
The Project for electrification of the outer islands will expand power supply systems or, in
some  cases,  replace  them  completely  on  about  40  outer  islands  in  the  Maldives.  This  will
provide  improved  power  supply  to  about  8,500  households  with  a  total  population  of  about
45,000  people.  The  Project  also  supports  ADB's  policy  on  private  sector  development  by
encouraging  the  participation  of  island  communities  and  attempting  to  instill  a  culture  of
accountability  and  self-governance  in  outer  island  power  supply  utilities.  A  representative
sample of six islands was selected for the economic evaluation of the Project. The islands were
surveyed  in  detail  to  determine  the  condition  of  their  existing  power  supply  systems  and  the
expected load growth, and to prepare plans for expansion. The islands that will participate in the
Project are islands that are selected as focus islands under the Government's development plan
for the outer islands, but are not currently served by STELCO.  Typically, these islands will have
populations  between  300  and  1,500.  Smaller  islands  are  normally  not  included  under  the
development focus program, and larger islands are in most cases already served by STELCO.
To participate in the sector loan for the Project, the development of power supply on each island
must be economically justified with an EIRR of at least 10 percent.

83.
The existing power supply systems on these islands are normally owned and operated
by the local IDCs, NGOs, or small private companies. Practically all households on each island
are connected to some form of electricity. Total installed generation capacities are typically 50
kW to 150 kW at present.  Due to their inefficiency, high losses, and small size, average costs of

 22

electricity are high, with average tariffs of about Rf4.00 ($0.31) per kWh.  Most electricity is used
for  residential  purposes  -  lighting,  and  operation  of  television  sets,  radios,  fans,  washing
machines, and other electrical appliances.  However, electricity is not used for cooking, since it is
much more costly than firewood or kerosene. Government offices and public services, such as
schools  and  streetlights,  are  also  significant  electricity  users.  On  the  larger  islands,  there  are
also commercial consumers.

2.

Least-Cost Power Supply Plans

The distribution systems are in poor condition on most islands, with distribution losses of
84.
20-30  percent.  Voltage  levels  at  the  ends  of  the  line  are  also  unsatisfactory  during  high  load
periods.  The  plans  for  developing  and  expanding  power  supplies  under  the  Project  include
completely  replacing  the  distribution  systems  in  cases  where  they  are  inefficient  and
inadequate, or upgrading and expanding distribution as required to meet the load growth.  The
Project will also replace inefficient diesel generating sets, and add new diesel generating sets
as required to serve the load growth. Diesel-based systems are the most economic option for
these small power supply systems.

3.

Economic and Financial Evaluation

For the economic analysis, the economic benefits of the Project are divided into two parts.
85.
The  first  is  the  cost  savings  due  to  replacing  inefficient  generating  units  and  distribution  cables
that  have  inadequate  capacity.  The  change  will  improve  generation  efficiency,  and  reduce
distribution  losses  and  operating  costs  for  existing  levels  of  sales.  The  second  benefit  is  the
additional  electricity  sales  arising  from  the  Project  due  to  future  load  growth.  These  additional
sales  are  valued  in  the  economic  analysis  at  the  average  consumer  willingness  to  pay  for
electricity consumption. This average economic value was based on an electricity demand curve
derived from data for various islands in the Maldives, and is estimated to be about 70-80 percent
higher than existing average tariff levels.

86.
The  economic  evaluation  of  each  of  the  six  islands  selected  for  project  evaluation  is
described  in  Appendix  13.  The  overall  Project  has  an  estimated  EIRR  of  19.4 percent  for  the
base  case.  However,  the  economic  evaluation  of  benefits  is  conservative,  as  no  attempt  was
made to evaluate the benefits of improved reliability and quality of power supply.

87.
Sensitivity analysis indicates that the economic performance of the Project is robust for
large  increases  in  fuel  costs  or  capital  costs.  The  Project  can  tolerate  a  doubling  of  crude  oil
prices  and  still  remain  economic.  The  project  economics  are  most  sensitive  to  reductions  in
estimated unit benefits. The Project would become uneconomic if average benefit rates for new
sales is reduced more than 32 percent, based on a minimum 10 percent EIRR, or if total load
growth is reduced by more than 30 percent.

88.
The  financial  evaluation  assumes  that  tariffs  will  be  set  to  achieve  breakeven  cost
recovery  (including  operating  costs  plus  debt-service  costs).  Figure  A13.2  in  Appendix  13
illustrates  the  reductions  in  future  tariff  rates  that  are  feasible  and  expected  on  this  basis  for
each  island.  Over  a  period  of  time,  average  tariff  levels  on  the  six  islands  will  be  about  13
percent lower in real terms by 2006.  With such future tariffs, the average financial internal rate
of  return  (FIRR)  for  the  overall  Project  is  estimated  to  be  3.4  percent,  which  is  more  than  the
weighted  average  financial  cost  of  capital  of  2.8  percent  (in  real  terms)  for  the  Project.
Therefore, the FIRR for this Project is satisfactory.

 B.

Social Dimensions

23

A  social  assessment  was  conducted  during  project  formulation.  During  the  process,
89.
comprehensive  consultations  with  beneficiaries  and  surveys 
in  several  representative
subproject  sites  were  carried  out.  There  is  agreement  in  all  islands  about  the  need  for  an
improved  electricity  supply  although  most  populations  in  the  outer  islands  are  connected  to
some  form  of  electricity.  A  good  electricity  supply  for  24  hours  a  day  is  a  high  priority  for
households  with  less  than  that.  Where  households  already  have  24  hours  supply,  the  level  of
desire  for  improvements  is  demonstrated  by  their  stated  willingness  to  spend  more  of  their
savings for buying electrical appliances. Further evidence is shown by the considerable effort of
communities  to  improve  their  electricity  supply  systems  through  communal  fund-raising
activities. This confirms the strong absorptive capacity of the island communities for the Project.

The  majority  of  the  electricity  consumers  in  the  outer  islands  consume  an  average  of
90.
around 25 kWh per month and consumption in the lowest quartile is 12 kWh per month. Those
in the lowest quartile are generally able to pay for their level of consumption at around 5 percent
or  less  of  household  income.  Households  currently  using  less  than  10  kWh  per  month  do  not
have the ability to pay higher tariffs and have less resources to generate increased income from
an improved electricity supply. The major benefit to these households will come from reduced
tariffs as a result of improved efficiency. Based on the analysis of a representative sample of six
islands, the overall tariff in real terms is expected to decline by about 13 percent by 2006.

91. With  a  more  reliable  and  adequate  electricity  supply,  outer  island  communities  will
receive nonfinancial benefits as well. A reliable electricity supply will allow them to put electric
lighting in schools or electric refrigerators in community health clinics, or to access electricity for
lighting  or  for  electrical  appliances  for  household  businesses.  The  Project  is  also  expected  to
facilitate  the  development  of  other  basic  infrastructure  such  as  better  health,  education,  and
information communication facilities, and thereby improve access to and productivity in the labor
market. With improved efficiency of the sector and the economy, the indirect effects of improved
access to electricity services will also be evident in the increase in total wealth and the release
of more funds for other activities. The indirect effect will benefit the island populations both as
members of society and as consumers.

92.
The  survey  of  the  sample  islands  shows  that  improved  electricity  supply  will  benefit
general family welfare, particularly of women.  Where there is sufficient disposable income for
electrical  appliances,  the  increased  use  of  flatirons  and  washing  machines  will  relieve  the
domestic workload of women. A reliable electricity supply will enable more home-based income-
generating  opportunities  such  as  rope  making  in  the  evening.  For  higher  income  households,
increased  availability  of  electricity  will  provide  opportunities  for  increased  household  income
through activities such as sewing, production of freezer goods, and computer and fax services.

C.

Impact on Poverty

93.
Poverty  in  the  Maldives  is  largely  shown  by  the  regional  disparities  between  Malé  and
the outer islands. Despite the fact that macroeconomic indicators in recent years have recorded
marked improvement in the Maldives, the benefits of growth have not been equitably distributed
to the populations. Furthermore, the decentralization of economic activities away from Malé has
been  hampered  by  lack  of  basic  infrastructure  and  institutional  capacities  in  the  outer  islands.
The Project supports the Government's policy to reduce poverty by improving electricity supply
in the outer islands, which in turn will help to achieve balanced economic growth and equitable
regional development.

 24

94.
One  of  the  underlying  objectives  of  the  Project  is  to  give  poor  households  and
communities  in  the  outer  islands  a  reliable  and  adequate  supply  of  electricity.  The  Project  will
have  important  and  direct  effects  on  the  poor  through  (i)  easier  establishment  and  increased
productivity of businesses that will employ the poor, (ii) creation of employment in infrastructure
construction, (iii) improved health and education and savings in time and effort that will increase
individual productivity, and (iv) longer operating life of electrical appliances.

95.
The  Project  will  directly  benefit  about  8,500  households  with  a  population  of  45,000  in
about  40  focus  islands.  Although  income  poverty  exists  everywhere  in  the  country,  certain
islands have a concentration of the poor.  The VPA report shows that 26 percent of the income
poor are located on 20 islands, and 8 of the focus islands to be considered under the Project
are within the group of the 20 poorest islands. The report further indicates that the percentage of
people  living  under  the  poverty  line  of  Rf15  per  person  per  day  in  the  focus  islands  is  50
percent,  which  is  higher  than  the  country  average  of  42  percent,  and  more  than  double  the
percentage in Malé.

A poverty impact ratio (PIR) expressing the proportion of net economic benefits accruing
96.
to  the  poor  was  calculated  by  comparing  the  net  economic  benefits  to  the  poor  with  the  net
economic benefits to the economy as a whole. The project preparatory TA report indicates that
the  GDP  of  the  poor  in  the  focus  islands  is  approximately  11  percent  of  the  total  GDP  of  the
country.    This  implies  that  the  Project  will  have  a  positive  poverty  reduction  impact  when  PIR
exceeds  11  percent.  The  TA  report  confirms  that  the  Project  will  have  a  significant  positive
poverty  reduction  impact  since  the  PIR  averages  32  percent  for  the  sample  representative
islands  as  a  whole,  and  exceeds  11  percent  in  all  islands  that  were  selected  for  project
evaluation.

D.

Risks

The Project is technically simple and straightforward. However, its success depends on
97.
(i)  the  ability  of  the  IA  to  implement  the  project;  (ii)  establishment  of  national  codes  and
standards for power suppliers and consumers, and enforcement of such codes and standards;
(iii)  the  Government's  strong  will  for  enacting  new  legislation  or  amending  existing  laws  to
provide for the establishment of legal power supply utilities on the outer islands, or recognition
of  the  island  community  groups  as  legal  entities;  (iv)  willingness  of  stakeholders  to  borrow
money from the Government to establish an upgraded power supply system; (v) availability of
skilled  human  resources  for  proper  maintenance  and  management  of  the  power  supply
systems; and (vi) appropriate  tariff levels to ensure the financial viability of outer island power
supply  utilities.    As  for  the  last  risk,  the  project  FIRR  and  EIRR  for  the  representative  islands
were tested for these sensitivities and found to be robust. Additionally, to mitigate the first risk,
the  IA  will  be  strengthened  by  consulting  services.  To  mitigate  the  second  risk,  in  addition  to
consulting services for establishing national codes and standards, covenants were agreed upon
to  ensure  proper  regulation  and  enforcement  of  the  quality  and  safety  standards  of  electricity
supply.  With  respect  to  the  third  risk,  the  Government  has  agreed  to  prepare  and  submit  new
legislation  to  Parliament  for  approval  within  nine  months  of  loan  effectiveness,  which  is
covenanted  in  the  legal  documents.  To  mitigate  the  fourth  risk,  the  Government  agreed  to  a
covenant on conducting awareness campaigns and training workshops for project beneficiaries
and island communities in addition to providing soft term loans. The fifth risk is to be mitigated
by  building  the  capacity  of  the  outer  island  power  supply  utilities  under  the  Project  in  power
supply system maintenance and management skills.

A.

Introduction

The  project  feasibility  study  carried  out  under  the  Asian  Development  Bank's  (ADB’s)
1.

evaluation  of  the  potential  for  renewable  resources  (photovoltaic  [PV])  power  and  also  windmill
power)  to  generate  electricity  in  the  Maldives.1  The  project  design  concept  for  both  PV  and
windmill  power  was  to  incorporate  them  into  integrated  diesel-renewable  power  supply  systems
for the outer islands. This design is required to provide reliability, since wind is often very light or
even absent, and the sun is only available during daylight hours.  This hybrid design is also more
economic  than  a  power  supply  system  based  entirely  on  renewable  energy  sources  with  large
battery  storage  capacity.  Substantial  experience  with  these  renewable  energy  technologies  has
been accumulated over the years, including experience on small islands in many countries in the
Pacific  Ocean,  which  are  similar  to  the  Maldives.    Adequate  data  was  also  available  in  the
Maldives on local conditions for solar insolation, and for hourly wind speed records over a period
of several years at three airports.

2.
The TA study concluded  that these renewable energy components for power supply were
not economic for the outer islands in the Maldives. Average economic costs for such renewable
energy  sources  would  be  more  than  $1.00  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh),  and  the  benefits  are  only  a
small fraction of this, about $0.12-$0.14 per kWh, based on fuel cost savings, reduced operation
and maintenance (O&M) expenses, and also the global environmental benefits of reduced carbon
dioxide  emissions.  The  results  of  this  economic  analysis  are  summarized  in  Table  A3.1.  There
was some concern that perhaps the  estimated project costs  and benefits  from  these renewable
energy technologies might have been too conservative. Therefore ADB engaged another group of
staff  consultants  to  undertake  a  new  and  independent  evaluation  of  these  renewable  energy
technologies  during  project  processing  at  the  fact-finding  and  appraisal  missions.  The  results  of
the independent evaluation are also summarized in Table A3.1.

B.

Economic Analysis

1.

Photovoltaic Power Generation

3.
A demonstration project for a PV-diesel power supply system was designed for the island
of Hanimaadhoo, in Haa Dhaalu atoll.  This island, with a population of 840 people, currently has
a  peak  daily  load  of  about  60  kW,  and  several  diesel  generating  sets  with  400  kW  of  total
capacity.    With  some  future  load  growth,  it  could  accommodate  an  integrated  PV  power
component  of  40  kW,  which  would  be  adequate  to  serve  most  of  the  daytime  load.    The  bare-
bones cost of PV power panels is about $3,000-$4,000 per kW, but after all the control equipment,
storage batteries, and equipment for inverters and converters to supply 220 volts (V) alternating
current (AC) power are added to this, the entire integrated PV system will cost about $14,000 per
kW  of  PV  capacity.  This  is  much  higher  than  the  cost  of  diesel  generating  sets,  which  is  only
about $200 per kW for a basic diesel generator set of 100 kW, and about 50 percent more after all
the  control  equipment,  and  a  share  of  building  costs  and  fuel  storage  costs  are  added.
Consequently,  the  initial  capital  investment  required  for  a  PV  system  is  about  50  times  that  for
diesel generating sets.

2.

Windmill Power Generation

5.
Windmill  power  generation  was  also  evaluated.  In  an  integrated  windmill-diesel  power
system,  the  maximum  proportion  of  windmill  power  that  can  be  accommodated  is  restricted  to
about 15 percent of the total power production.  With more windmill generation, the power supply
system would become unstable. The windmill power system that was designed initially in the TA
study  for  a  typical  island  was  only  for  15  kW,  and  this  resulted  in  high  average  costs  of  about
$16,600  per  kW  for  the  windmill  component.  During  appraisal,  the  focus  shifted  to  larger  outer
islands  that  could  accommodate  a  larger  windmill  system  of  about  40  kW.  This  reduced  the
average  costs  of  capacity  (Table  A3.2).  However,  the  estimated  average  annual  capacity  factor
was  also  reduced  in  the  appraisal  stage  reevaluation,  based  on  a  detailed  analysis  of  historic
hourly wind records in the Maldives. The resulting average cost of renewable energy produced by
the  windmill  component  was  $1.09  per  kWh  at  appraisal,  which  is  still  much  too  high.  Average
wind  speeds  in  the  Maldives  are  relatively  low,  which  is  common  at  tropical  latitudes.2  Power
generation with windmills is very sensitive to wind speed, and increases in proportion to the cubic
power of wind speed. The average capital costs of windmill generating sets are also very sensitive
to  economies  of  scale,  and  decrease  with  increasing  size.  The  economic  optimum  unit  size  is
usually in the range of 150-250 kW or larger, with the maximum practical unit size close to 1,000
kW. Consequently, with the low generating unit sizes required in the outer islands and low wind
speeds in the Maldives, wind power generation will be much more costly than in other countries
with  more  favorable  conditions.3    The  economies  of  scale  that  have  led  to  very  large,  cost
competitive windmill farms in the People's Republic of China, Denmark, Germany, India, and US,
with large unit sizes and clusters of many windmill generators in one “farm” are not available in the
outer islands in the Maldives.

7.
Many barriers are also associated with using renewable energy to generate power in the
Maldives.  Although  the  technology  has  been  demonstrated  to  be  feasible  in  other  countries,
usually  more  advanced,  there  is  little  experience  with  O&M  of  such  systems  in  the  Maldives.
Experience  in  other  developing  countries  with  limited  technical  skills  has  shown  that  improper
operation, inadequate maintenance and periodic replacement of worn equipment, and inability to
repair  these  systems  in  case  of  breakdown  are  serious  problems,  and  often  result  in  projects'
breaking  down  permanently  after  only  a  few  years  of  operation.  Technical  skills  for  operating
sophisticated new equipment are limited in the Maldives, especially in the outer islands. The plan
for the renewable energy component of the Project also included a $3 million program for removal
of these barriers to promote renewable energy technologies; that amount is not even included in
the project costs and economic analysis described here. The coastal marine environment in the
Maldives is also a potential problem with power windmills.  Windmill power projects in the Pacific
islands have experienced high rates of equipment corrosion and breakdown due to salt-laden air
and  coastal  spray,  high  humidity  levels,  and  high  temperatures.    These  factors  could  result  in
useful project lifetimes much lower than the 20 years assumed for the base case in this study. If
the project lifetime is only 10 years, the B/C will decline to only 0.083 for PV power systems and
0.078 for the windmill power systems.

D.

Conclusions

8.
These  renewable  energy  technologies  (hybrid  PV-diesel  and  windmill-diesel)  are  not
economically  justified  for  power  supply  in  the  outer  islands  in  the  Maldives  at  present,  to  serve
communities of the size required for this Project, which are typically 100 or more households in a
reasonably compact community center on each island. Power supply with diesel generating units
and local distribution grids is much more economic, with each kWh costing only about one tenth
the average cost for renewable energy generation. It is not likely that the average capital costs of
renewable energy will decline significantly in the near future, but if there are significant reductions,
the  feasibility  can  be  reassessed.  Although  electricity  supplied  from  PV  household  modules  is
widely used in many developing countries, it is costly in most cases and is practiced only where
households are far removed from a community grid, or where power supply from that grid is very
unreliable. The average costs of PV electricity supply in the project sizes considered for this study
(40 kW) already achieve full economies of scale, and average costs will not decline significantly
with large PV project sizes.  Average costs for windmill power systems will decrease with larger
unit  sizes  and  with  clusters  of  multiple  units,  but  these  would  then  be  too  large  for  the  outer
islands in the Maldives. Even in Malé, the economic feasibility of larger windmill power clusters will
be affected by the low average wind speeds in the Maldives.

B.

Investment Projections

The capital expenditures for each of the islands evaluated are based on the investment
2.
requirements  set  out  during  the  forecast  period  up  to  2010.  It  was  assumed  that  investments
incurred  up  to  2005  would  be  covered  or  financed  under  the  Project,  and  subsequent
investments for replacements or expansions were assumed to be arranged by the island power
supply  utilities  themselves.  The  capital  costs  are  defined  as  base  costs  (as  estimated  by  the
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  consultants)  plus  10  percent  physical  contingencies
and  12.5  percent  taxes  and  duties  on  the  foreign  exchange  components.  Price  contingencies
are taken into account, to reflect price changes during the forecast period, i.e., by inflating these
costs by the domestic inflation rates.

C.

Electricity Sales, Revenues, and Tariffs

Electricity  sales  and  generation  for  each  island  utility  are  based  on  the  demand
3.
projections for each island. The growth situation in each island is unique, i.e., in some of these
islands, like Funadhoo and Muli for example, populations are expected to increase substantially
in the next few years as the Government declared Funadhoo a resettlement island, and Muli as
a  atoll  capital.  In  such  cases,  electricity  demand  and  sales  are  projected  to  increase
substantially  in  line  with  this  population  growth.  In  general,  electricity  demand  in  the  outer
islands  has  been  suppressed  due  to  unreliable  and  limited  supply.  With  the  Project,  system
losses  are  expected  to  reduce  to  10  percent  (Table  A10)  from  the  current  20-30  percent,  and
reliability will improve as each island will have sufficient generating capacity to supply electricity
for 24 hours a day.

4.
Revenues  over  the  forecast  period  are  based  on  total  sales  (kilowatt-hour  [kWh])  per
annum by the island power supply utilities in the sample islands at the projected financial tariffs
generally ranging from Rf3.50 to Rf6.0. These tariffs were set based on a minimum cash break-
even principle, i.e., revenues should be sufficient to cover operating costs, the greater portion of
depreciation  or  debt  service  requirement,  and  the  need  to  ensure  that  cumulative  cash  flow
remains positive. Compared with the existing tariffs, the projected tariffs in many islands show
improvements (see projected tariffs in Table 3 of the main text). The Project will reduce the high
system  losses,  increase  efficiency,  and  thus  provide  increased  profitability  from  higher  sales
volume  and  lower  operating  costs.  In  general,  due  to  high  operating  costs,  current  tariffs  are
only sufficient to finance ongoing operation and maintenance (O&M) in many islands, and they
cannot cover the full cost of capital replacement. In many cases, the Government provided the
islands  with  free  generators,  so  many  of  them  are  not  aware  that  they  will  bear  the  costs  of

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION

A.

Introduction

An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  carried  out  by  the  project  preparatory
1.
technical assistance (TA) consultants for a representative eight sample islands1 in accordance
with ADB's environmental assessment requirements and environmental review procedures. The
IEE  was  discussed  and  formally  submitted  to  the  Government  in  January  2001  as  part  of  the
final TA report.

B.

2.

C.

Description of the Project

Description of the Environment

A detailed description of the Project is given in para. 46-47 of the main text.

All the sample islands visited were typical atoll islands, only a meter or two above mean
3.
sea  level.    Soils  are  generally  poor  and  sandy.  The  islands  vary  from  9  to  220  hectares  (ha),
and  population  density  from  4  to  64  people  per  ha.  Little  in  the  way  of  land  mammals  were
sighted, other than the occasional domesticated cat. Bird life was not prolific.

4.
Human  settlements  were  closely  spaced,  following  a  rectangular  grid  pattern  of  roads.
Roads  were  generally  laid  out  on  a  rectangular  basis,  and  were  soft  coral  sand.  None  of  the
roads in the sample islands were sealed. Generally, the settlements were close to the center of
the  islands,  but  in  more  densely  populated  islands  sometimes  spanned  the  full  width  of  the
island with a band of vegetation between the outermost houses and the ocean shore.

5.
On  most  islands  each  house  is  surrounded  by  a  2-meter-high  plastered  coral  block
fence. This usually enclosed a number of small residential structures and a building for cooking
and food preparation. Older houses had few external windows, but newly constructed ones had
barred windows of a moderate size.

Fishing boats, cargo boats, and passenger boats are essential to island life. Numerous
6.
boats are generally moored in a well-defined area or areas and, where provided, in harbors. All
islands  without  harbors  wanted  to  construct  a  harbor  by  dredging  the  reef.  Reclaiming  land
using  sand  and  material  dredged  from  the  reef  is  also  a  favored  development  activity.
Organized farming is limited, even on those islands classified as agricultural.

7.
All the islands had a freshwater table close to the surface. On some islands, this water is
highly polluted and unsuitable for washing or drinking. On other islands, the water is suitable for
washing,  but  is  not  used  for  drinking,  except  in  emergencies.  Rainwater  from  house  or
communal tanks is the main source of drinking water.

8.
On  many  islands,  solid  waste  is  dumped  on  the  surface  just  inside  the  forest  line.  A
considerable  amount  of  solid  waste  finds  its  way  into  the  ocean  and  is  washed  up  on  the
beaches.  It  is  evident  that  both  increased  population  and  increased  development  is  stressing
the environment. While the central residential areas of the islands were generally clean and well
cared for by the community, there seemed to be little general awareness of the fragility of the
ecology on atoll islands or of the steps that need to be taken to protect the environment.

D.

Screening of Potential Environmental Impact and Mitigating Measures

9.
A  minor  short-term  potential  environmental  impact  derives  from  the  installation  of
generators and cables. There will be a potentially more long-term environmental impact from the
operation of the power stations. The following paragraphs describe the potential environmental
impacts and their mitigating measures.

1.

Construction

a.

Power Station Buildings

10.
Existing  power  station  buildings  will  be  used  where  possible.  Few  buildings  will  be
constructed  under  the  Project,  and  they  will  be  small,  no  bigger  than  a  house,  and  will  use
building  materials  and  skills  commonly  available  on  the  outer  islands.  Where  a  new  power
station is required, land and clearing requirements will be small. Population relocation will not be
required.

11. Where  required,  existing  power  stations  will  be  modified  to  mitigate  environmental
effects.  Such  work  will  be  minor  and  will  be  limited  to  sealing  existing  buildings,  providing
sound-proof air vents, and establishing bulk fuel tanks and bunded oil-handling areas.

b.

Underground Distribution Cables

12.
All cables will be low voltage. In almost all locations, they will be buried along the side of
existing  unsealed  roadways.  They  will  be  protected  from  interference  by  burial  depth  and  by
steel wire armoring.

13.
All cables will be covered with an inert polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sheath. The trenches will
be  opened  for  only  a  short  while,  as  the  sandy  soil  conditions  are  such  that  a  trench  would
collapse if left open. No trees will be cleared for the distribution works.

14.
At  the  level  of  voltage  proposed,  there  will  be  no  transformers  and  no  high-voltage
switchgear. Under the proposed design, there is no possibility for using polychlorinated biphenyl
(PCB) oils; however, if capacitors are to be used to correct a low load factor, it is recommended
that  the  specification  exclude  the  use  of  PCB  oils.  PCB  oils  are  cancer  causing,  and  as  they
break down in the soil or water table, spills or leaks eventually enter the food chain. No negative
environmental impact has been identified, other than the remote possibility that PCB oils may be
used in capacitors, if capacitors are installed.

2.

Operation

a.

Powerhouse Operation

15.
Diesel  Oil  Transport.  Transporting  oil  to  the  islands  appears  to  be  carried  out  safely.
Some  islands  receive  their  supply  from  bulk  tankers  that  are  operated  either  by  the  State
Trading Organization (STO) or by private entrepreneurs. This simple operation was carried out
competently and without any spillage. The tanker crew observed accepted safety practices, and
appeared to have the operation well under control at all times. Most oil is carried to the island in
200  liter  drums  on  the  routine  cargo  boat  supplying  the  island.  This  oil  in  drums  is  usually
purchased  from  Malé,  but  one  island  purchased  its  oil  from  Kulhudhuffushi.  Some  utilities

 56

Appendix 11, page 3

purchased fuel oil from bulk stores on their own island. Transporting oil by drums seems a safe
method of transport. Empty drums are returned for reuse.

16.
Although  reef  damage  resulting  from  the  anchors  of  the  many  general  cargo  and
passenger boats is evident, there is no evidence of damage to the reef by the anchors of boats
specifically involved in fuel transportation.

17.
Diesel  and  Lubricating  Oil  Spillage.  There  is  very  little  evidence  of  oil  having  been
spilled at the fuel storage or handling areas. However, where there was significant oil spillage,
no action was taken to remove the contaminated sand from the site. Education and monitoring
of  cleaning  up  after  oil  spills  are  required.  The  Ministry  of  Home  Affairs,  Housing  and
Environment (MHHE) will establish officers on each atoll to regulate environmental compliance
and  provide  environmental  education.  The  officer  will  be  able  to  take  adequate  steps  to
minimize the damage caused by minor spills.

18.
In general, oil storage facilities are poor. Where they exist, bulk tanks are generally not
bunded, nor is the surrounding area concreted. Even though diesel oil is rated as combustible,
often oil is stored in a manner that presents a considerable fire risk to the power station and to
the neighboring residences. In more than one location, oil was stored inside the power station.
In  one  location  the  oil  was  stored  inside  the  power  station  in  a  2,000-liter  plastic  water  tank,
which has the potential for splitting.

19.
Under  the  Project,  bulk  tanks  will  be  installed  at  all  power  stations  where  they  are
required.  The  tanks  will  be  at  least  5  meters  removed  from  the  station  building,  bunded  with
concrete  lining  within  the  bund.  Under  the  Project,  drum  handling  areas  should  be  concreted
and fitted with interceptor drains.

20.
Disposal and Handling of Waste Lubricating Oil. Lubricating oil is generally stored in
200-liter  drums  near  the  power  station.  In  most  locations  waste  lubricating  oil  is  greatly  in
demand for treating timber. On one island, waste lubricating oil is buried in a hole in the beach,
and  in  another  it  is  dumped  into  a  well.  On  both  islands,  the  power  station  managers  thought
they were behaving responsibly. Where oil has contaminated the soil, the soil should be dug up
and  entombed  in  concrete,  so  that  the  oil  does  not  flow  down  to  the  water  table.  Waste
lubricating  oil  contains  low-level  carcinogens.  Care  should  be  taken  to  prevent  skin  contact
when handling the waste oil. As the general public is not aware of this danger, it may be better
to discourage the sale of waste lubricating oil.

21.
Power  station  managers  need  to  be  trained  in  environmentally  acceptable  disposal
systems. Probably the simplest method of disposal is to mix waste lubricating oil with diesel fuel
and utilize it as fuel. Engine manufacturers accept that waste lubricating oil at a maximum rate
of 5 percent can be mixed with fuel oil. Thus 10 liters of waste lubricating oil can be added to
200 liters of fuel oil. The mixture should be stirred well, preferably shortly before use. Provision
has been made in the project estimates for such training.

Noise. All the power stations in the sample were unnecessarily noisy. Some engines did

not even have silencers. Project estimates allow for power stations on the project islands to be
sealed  and  noise  baffles  fitted  to  air  inlets  and  radiator  air  outlets,  where  this  is  required.

on all new engines, and replacing existing silencers that are currently inadequate.

speed  diesel  generating  sets,  and  20  years  for  the  underground  distribution  cables.  Diesel
generating sets need to be replaced when they reach the end of this lifetime.

11.
The total investment required to improve power supply and meet the load growth for the
period up to 2005 (inclusive) for the six representative islands evaluated for this Project would be
$1.2 million in base costs, which is equivalent to an average investment of about $180 per person
served.  This  compares  with  an  average  per  capita  cash  income  on  the  outer  islands  of  about
$800 annually.

C.

12.

in  the  TA  study.  For  Naalaafushi,  a  new  generating  unit  was  recently  installed,  and  no  more
capacity is needed for the planned duration of the Project up to 2005.  For Veyvah, the island is
very small, and with a reduced and more realistic forecast of load growth, it was not economically
feasible  to  expand  power  supply  to  a  high  standard.  On  the  remaining  six  islands,  it  is

Financial Evaluation of the Project

The financial evaluation differs from the economic in that financial prices are used for all
14.
project costs, which include duties and taxes on capital costs and fuel costs. Project benefits are

that electricity tariffs will be reduced on each island, as shown in Figures A13.2 and A13.3, so
that  each  island  will  achieve  cash  breakeven,  including  payment  of  debt-service  costs.  The
overall tariff rate in real prices (adjusted for inflation) is expected to decline by about 13 percent
by  2006.  The  resulting  financial  internal  rates  of  return  (FIRR)  for  each  island  are  shown  in
Table  A13.4.  The  average  FIRR  for  the  overall  project  is  estimated  to  be  3.4  percent  in  real
terms, without inflation. The FIRR is relatively low because tariffs on each island will be kept as
low  as  possible,  while  maintaining  cash  breakeven.  However,  the  FIRR  is  still  higher  than  the
weighted average cost of capital of 2.8 percent in real terms (net of inflation).

15.
The  Project's  financial  feasibility  is  more  robust  to  changes  in  the  main  variables  than
indicated  in  the  sensitivity  analysis  (Table  A13.5).  In  the  event  of  an  unexpected  increase  in
project  capital  costs,  or  fuel  costs,  or  change  in  forecast  sales,  the  average  tariff  could  be
adjusted to achieve a satisfactory financial rate of return. In the case of crude oil prices higher
than $25 per barrel, average tariffs would have to increase about $0.0025 for each $1 per barrel
in  oil  costs.  A  large  tariff  increase  would  in  turn  have  some  impact  on  load  growth,  but  if
expansion plans are adjusted for this, the longer term impacts can be accommodated.
